ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: 5 hours per week, 15 hours the week before the presentation
2-4 on averageI spent about 10 hours the week that I presented in class
4 hours
2 hrs; much more if you're presenting that week.

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: Loved that the course was discussion based
great way to practice epi skills with focus on perinatal topics

Strengths: very discussion based. Gives students a great opportunity to hone epidemiology skill, ask questions, and take some leadership of a topic of interest.Weaknesses: It would have been nice to a have a bit more instructor-led background on the topic of perinatal epidemiology.

The course was strong in teaching about perinatal epidemiology methods. The student-led format did not lend itself well to getting a foundation of perinatal public health. We also did not receive feedback throughout the course.
Great discussion format. You learn a lot about different current topics in perinatal health. I liked learning from classmates and having productive discussions.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Adrienne Ettinger  Excellent. Dr. Ettinger was a good discussion leader, with provocative questions for students and good experience to draw from (particularly in the field of nutrition and environmental exposures).
Instructor: Adrienne Ettinger  She was experienced and I definitely learned from her lectures and comments.
Instructor: Adrienne Ettinger  Great! Facilitated discussions well with insightful comments and responsive to questions.

Instructor: Kathleen Belanger  Very good. Dr. Belanger is a wealth of knowledge of perinatal epidemiology, and was a superb resource to have access to throughout this course. Her lecture style is a bit dry, but her level of knowledge is impressive.
Instructor: Kathleen Belanger  She was experienced and I definitely learned from her lectures and comments.
Instructor: Kathleen Belanger  Knowledgeable and was great at asking good questions during presentations.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Very interesting for anyone interesting in perinatal epidemiology, good practice with communication skills and critically evaluating peer reviewed articles
interesting topics, not a lot of work, intimate class setting

A largely student-led seminar on topics of interest to students a professors in the field of perinatal epidemiology. Students who have not had a year of epidemiology first should not take this course, as the course is almost a capstone to the epidemiology learning completed at YSPH. It's a great course to go out on as a graduating second-year MPH student because it solidifies a lot of concepts learned in other courses, and give students a chance to interact with material and ask questions.
The course was a good for reinforcing epidemiology methods. It was relatively unchallenging but the student led format made it a little less educational than it could have been.

Great way to learn in a small group setting. Be prepared to really analyze the papers and learn about a variety of different topics. The presentation was a great exercise in preparing for a prolonged presentation format.
